thread.title: Rangers offseason issue No. 5: Is bullpen capable of a season of success?
thread.title_full: Rangers offseason issue No. 5: Is bullpen capable of a season of success? | Dallas Morning News

author: Evan Grant
title: Rangers offseason issue No. 5: Is bullpen capable of a season of success?
text:
The Rangers may have had a hard time sleeping after their season came to an abrupt end Wednesday afternoon, but regardless, it's time to put 2015 to bed.
And it's time to start focusing on 2016, because, well, the business of baseball never ends.
With that in mind, here is the fifth of five major issues the Rangers will spend a significant amount of time trying to solve this winter:
The Rangers' bullpen was as strong a weapon as the team had in the second half, thanks to the rise of Shawn Tolleson as closer, the ascent of Keone Kela and the acquisitions of Jake Diekman and Sam Dyson.
Now come the consequences.
Counting the postseason, all four appeared in at least 70 games. Kela, a rookie, dealt with elbow inflammation in the final month of the season and will probably have a light offseason. Tolleson threw in five straight games in the final week of the regular season, and it was clear his arm was impacted. Dyson, a former starter, surpassed his previous professional high by 31 appearances.
It was amazing work. But given the nature and the stress of the job, the Rangers can't expect the quartet to be as resilient in 2016. It simply means the Rangers can't afford to overlook the bullpen in putting together the roster.
Luke Jackson gives the Rangers one enticing option as an insurance policy. Though Tanner Scheppers had a miserable season, the Rangers will have to think long and hard about whether to non-tender him in salary arbitration. Two years out from the failed experiment as a starter, he might be back to where he once was. And there will be a handful of attractive veterans on the free-agent market.
